items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely all day today, Tuesday 7th December 2021 and overnight tonight. Water levels continue to remain high. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th December 2021.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Following the heavy rainfall this morning due to Storm Barra, river levels are continuing to steadily rise on the Rivers Clyst and Culm. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible this afternoon, Tuesday 07/12/2021 and overnight. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Wednesday morning, 08/12/2021, or earlier if the situation changes.
River levels on the River Rye have fallen below the levels of concern. We continue to monitor the situation. Please check the .GOV website for up to date information for the next 5 days.

High tides and strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire coast on the evening of Tuesday 07/12/2021, between 4pm and midnight and on the morning of Wednesday 08/12/2021 between 6am and midday. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Tuesday evening, 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Tuesday's tides at 11:00 AM  and 11:45 PM will be higher than normal due to stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour side and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
We are closing flood gates in the area.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Tuesday's tide at 10:30 AM  and 00:30 AM on Wednesday will be higher than normal due to stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include The Quomps, Mudeford and the Stanpit area
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: River levels remain high at the Great Bridgford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Tuesday 07/12/2021. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook. Further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated this evening, Tuesday 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Hints river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high overnight and into Wednesday 08/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force as river levels remain high following rainfall over the weekend. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Tuesday 07/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast today and river levels could remain high until later in the week. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Tuesday afternoon, 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.70mAOD at 16:30 on 07/12/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 27 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:30 on 07/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30am to 3:30pm today, Tuesday 7th December 2021. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea seafront may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.7 mAODN at 1:30pm, on Tuesday 7th December, which is 0.32m above tide tables, wind Force 7, South Easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm today, Tuesday 7th December.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: High tides are forecast to bring high levels and large waves along the Yorkshire coast on Tuesday 07/12/2021, with the specific time of concern being Tuesday evening between 5pm and 7pm. Please be careful along beaches, coastal  footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Tuesday evening  07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding is possible for the duration of the strong winds, between 15:45 and 18:45 on Tuesday, 07/12/21.  Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, especially at Beadnell Harbour Rd North, Berwick Dock and Main Road. High winds and coastal conditions are expected to continue throughout the day and afternoon, and will start to ease during Tuesday evening, 07/12/21. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on 07/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences.  The first forecast high water is 21:00 on 07/12/21, with a level of 6.58 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is 09:15 on 08/12/21, with a level of 6.19 mAOD and a Force 8 Westerly wind.
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to coastal areas and the most vulnerable properties is possible tonight and tomorrow morning and may occur one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Strong winds are forecast again for Wednesday evening and this flood alert may remain in force for the high tide at 21:45.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30am to 3:30pm today, Tuesday 7th December 2021. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.5 mAODN at 1:30pm, on Tuesday 7th December, which is 0.28m above tide tables, wind Force 7, South Easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm today, Tuesday 7th December.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30am to 3:30pm today, Tuesday 7th December 2021. Tide levels will be high around the boatyard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.5 mAODN at 1:30pm, on Tuesday 7th December, which is 0.28m above tide tables, wind Force 7, South Easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm today, Tuesday 7th December.

Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the Fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.36mAODN at 2:00pm, on Tuesday 7th December, which is 0.27m above tide tables, wind Force 7, South Easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the forecast high water is 21:30am on 07/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.40 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 9 in a westerley direction. There is a possibility of flooding for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham, and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehamption Park, including Pill and Shirehampton, however conditions may apply one/two hours either side of the high tide.
Our operation teams are closing flood gates in the Pill and Shirehampton area. 
Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast on at 1 PM on 07/12/2021.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge between 2:30 PM and 3 PM on 07/12/2021.
River levels at Fiddlers Ferry will peak at 6.20m between 2 PM and 2.30 PM. 
River levels at Eastford Road will peak at 6.36m between 2:15 PM and 2:45 PM. 
River levels at Arpley Bridge will peak at 6.41m between 2.30 PM and 3 PM. 
High tides are also expected for tomorrow, Wednesday 8th December 2021
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

Strong winds from storm Barra are likely to cause high tidal peaks in the Wye Estuary. The tides will be at their highest at Newport between 21:00 and 22:00 this evening, 07/12/21 where they may exceed the flood alert threshold. 
Flooding is possible and may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.2m to 7.4m at 21:15 on 07/12, Newport 7.0m to 7.2m at 21:15 on 07/12.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning by 10am, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Tuesday. Flooding is possible over high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. 

High water at Ilfracombe is at 08:15 PM on Tuesday 07/12/2021 and at 08:30 AM on Wednesday 08/12/2021, times of high water will vary along the coast. Force 9 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 9.7m are forecast, which could result in wave overtopping of sea defences and localised flooding in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be up to 0.6m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Tuesday 07/12/2021 at 08:15 PM is 4.81 mAOD, this is 0.60 metres above astronomical tide level.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding is possible for the duration of the strong winds, between 15:15 and 20:00 on Tuesday, 07/12/21.  Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, especially at North Shields Western Quay Prom, Seaburn Lower Prom, Roker Seafront, Hendon Promenade, Seaham Harbour and Docks. High winds and coastal conditions are expected to continue throughout the day and afternoon, and will start to ease during Tuesday evening, 07/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on 07/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds and moderate waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.46 m. The total forecast tide is 5.38 metres Chart Datum (2.65 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, the water level will be very high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park, Langstone, will flood. Water may flow across the A259 junction with Lumley Road, flooding driveways. Road flooding will affect the bottom third of Langstone High Street. The depth of flood water in roads may be up to 0.2 m. At 01:45 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide may be similar in magnitude. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. In Emsworth, to protect property, we will install drop boards at The Promenade (southern end of the Mill Pond). If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, Mill Lane, Sidlesham will flood, making access temporarily more difficult. Wind blown spray and wave overtopping will likely affect exposed beach top properties between Selsey Bill and Elmer. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, and flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. Avoid driving on Mill Lane at high tide. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, the tide could cause minor flooding to boatyards and the industrial areas along Littlehampton Rope Walk and could be high up slipways. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, shallow water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front. Water will pond in Climping Street Car Park and may flow westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels and flood risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. We recycled shingle in November and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.24 m. The total forecast tide is 5.06 metres Chart Datum (2.32 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water could be near to or flood front door steps. Around Chichester harbour, some gardens or land at shore side properties could also be affected. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels and flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding is expected at Roker Seafront for the duration of the strong winds, between 16:45 and 18:30 on Tuesday, 07/12/21. High winds and coastal conditions are expected to continue throughout the day and afternoon, and will start to ease during Tuesday evening, 07/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on 07/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington - Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion
items.message: High tides are forecast to bring high levels and large waves along the Yorkshire coast on the evening of Tuesday 07/12/2021.  The areas most at risk are Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion in Bridlington, and the specific time of most concern is between 5pm and 7pm on Tuesday 07/12/2021. Please keep away from flood water as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. To report an issue relating to river, tidal or coastal flooding, call our Incident Hotline number 0800 80 70 60. Be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation via our Check for Flooding Service on Gov.UK or via Floodline on 0345 988 1188. This message will be updated on Tuesday evening, 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Camel excluding Wadebridge and Chapel Amble
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at Padstow is at 19:36 on Tuesday 7th December and 07:59 on Wednesday 8th December, times of high water will vary along the coast.  

Strong Force 8 westerly winds, veering north westerly, and offshore wave heights of 6-10m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  

Locations particularly at risk include the A389 at Sladesbridge.  

Expect tides to be around 700mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.  

With strong wind and large waves seafront areas will be dangerous. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.     

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.   

This message will be updated on the morning of Wednesday 8th December.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Lands End to Chapel Porth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at St Ives is at 19:19 Tuesday 7th December and 07:44 Wednesday 8th December, times of high water will vary along the coast.  

Strong Force 8 westerly winds, veering north westerly, and offshore wave heights of  6-10m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour and the Causeway at Hayle.  

Expect tides to be around 700mm higher than predicted because of forecast weather conditions.  

With strong wind and large waves seafront areas will be dangerous. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.     

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.  

This message will be updated on the morning of Wednesday 8th December.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:41 and 14:34 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.6 m. The total forecast tide is 4.24 metres Chart Datum (2.24 mAOD) at Beaulieu. The tide is highest at the time of second high water. For 1 hour either side of high tide, water will flood into the garden of the Mill House on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. Palace Lane will also flood, making access to the village temporarily more difficult. At 01:18 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide may be slightly higher in magnitude. We will issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking or driving through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood the main road quickly. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:41 and 14:34 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to Storm Barra, which brings strong South Easterly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.54 m. The forecast tide level has increased since yesterday. The total forecast tide is now 5.26 metres Chart Datum (2.52 mAOD) at Southampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, levels in the lower River Itchen will increase as the incoming tide prevents water from flowing out to sea. Footpath flooding will affect parts of Riverside Park. The pub car park at Mansbridge, is likely to be flooded for a short period of time. The tide will not flood property, but as rain is also expected, some surface water flooding may affect the A27. At 01:18 and 03:18 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide will be slightly lower, but may still cause similar minor impact flooding. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. As a precautionary measure, please consider closing the defence gates around the pub. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

items.description: Somerset coast at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean
items.message:
The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences.  The first forecast high water is 21:00 on 07/12/21, with a level of 6.58 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is 09:15 on 08/12/21, with a level of 6.19 mAOD and a Force 8 Westerly wind.
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding of coastal areas including roads and farmland is possible at these times. However, conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are coastal areas at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean.  Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point and this flood alert is unlikely to be reissued during this period of spring tides. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences. The first forecast high water is 21:00 on 07/12/21, with a level of 6.58 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is 09:15 on 08/12/2021, with a level of 6.19 mAOD and a Force 8 Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level.
There is the possibility of flooding of the most vulnerable properties and this may occur one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk include properties on the lockside, businesses around the Harbour Masters office, Gibraltar Cottages and other low lying properties on the B3225 at Porlock Weir. High winds will continue during Wednesday but this flood warning is unlikely to be in force for the high tide at 21:45 due to falling high tides.

Please consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels are beginning to fall and there is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast continues to be unsettled over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the South Devon coast. 
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at Teignmouth is at 08:45 PM on Tuesday 07/12/2021 and at 09:00 AM on Wednesday 08/12/2021, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
Force 7 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 1.5m are forecast on Tuesday evening, which could result in wave overtopping of sea defences and localised flooding in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be up to 0.48m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes. 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Teignmouth on Tuesday 07/12/2021 at 08:45 PM is 2.34 mAOD, this is 0.48m above astronomical tide level.

items.description: South Devon coast from Dawlish Warren to Seaton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the South Devon coast. 
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at Exmouth is at 09:00 PM on Tuesday 07/12/2021 and at 09:15 AM on Wednesday 08/12/2021, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
Force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 1.6m are forecast on Tuesday evening, which could result in wave overtopping of sea defences and localised flooding in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be up to 0.33m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes. 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Exmouth on Tuesday 07/12/2021 at 09:00 PM is 2.12 mAOD, this is 0.33m above astronomical tide level.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:22 and 14:30 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.58 m. The total forecast tide is 3.96 metres Chart Datum (1.98 mAOD) at Lymington. The tide will be highest at the time of second high water. For 1 hour either side of high tide, water will flood the footpath near the Ship Inn pub, Town Quay. Saltgrass Lane will flood and be completely impassable to traffic. In Milford-on-Sea High Street, near the Smugglers Inn pub, the river will increase with the tide and come close to the top of the river bank, possibly flooding footpaths. The tide will not flood property. At 01:09 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide will be similar in magnitude. We will issue further advice. To protect property from flooding, at Keyhaven and Lymington, our tidal defence gates will be closed for 2 hours either side of high water. All private defence gates should be closed. Any cars parked at Saltgrass Lane will flood. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:41 and 14:34 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to Storm Barra, which brings strong South Easterly Force 7 winds. The forecast tide level has increased since yesterday. The weather will increase tide table values by 0.54 m. The total forecast tide is now 5.26 metres Chart Datum (2.52 mAOD) at Southampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, flooding will affect; the lower floor of Eling Tide Mill and Eling Lane. Road and car park flooding will occur at Ashlett Creek (Fawley), Woodmill Lane, the Quay and Ropewalk (Hamble), Rising Sun Pub (Warsash), Magazine Lane (Marchwood), Promenade and Shore Road (Hythe). Water will come close to property nearest the estuary at Testwood and will affect boat yards at Bursledon. At 01:18 and 03:18 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide will be slightly lower, but will still cause similar minor impact flooding. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid parking in low lying coastal car parks and plan driving routes to avoid the roads listed above. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.52 m. The total forecast tide is 4.90 metres Chart Datum (2.31 mAOD) at Cowes. For 1 hour either side of high water, flooding will affect sea front roads, esplanades and car parks across the island. Water will be high up slipways in Cowes, affecting Medina Road and the Floating Bridge. In East Cowes, sea water forced up through drains may cause minor impacts to the road at Albany Road. The ferry terminal car park at Yarmouth will also flood. At 01:46 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide may be of a similar magnitude. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. At Medina Road, near the Floating Bridge, the tide may rise to be approximately 0.1 m below the top of front door steps. As a precautionary measure, and if you have it, we recommend that flood protection is installed at Medina Road and Bridge Road at Yarmouth, 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds and moderate waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.46 m. The total forecast tide is 5.38 metres Chart Datum (2.65 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high tide, water may just exceed the top of the main slipway, flooding the road at Lower Quay, Fareham. The lower end of Wallington Shore Road will flood to a depth of 0.1 m. Some tidal spray and debris may affect the A27 at Portchester. At 01:45 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide may be similar in magnitude. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. We recommend that cars do not park at the lower end of Wallington Shore Road. At Lower Quay, as a precautionary measure, and if you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

floodArea.riverOrSea: The Solent, Portsmouth Harbour, Langstone Harbour

items.message: Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds and moderate waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.46 m. The total forecast tide is 5.38 metres Chart Datum (2.65 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, in Old Portsmouth, the tide may just exceed the top of the main slipway which will cause minor road flooding in East Street and to the boat yards at The Camber. Spray overtopping of defence walls at Southsea promenade and Eastern Road is also expected. To protect property in Old Portsmouth, tidal defence gates will be closed. At 01:45 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide may be similar in magnitude. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. We are liaising with the local authority over flood defence gate closures. Avoid walking at exposed sea front locations at high tide. Spray and waves may carry and throw shingle and debris onto roads and footpaths. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.46 m. The total forecast tide is 5.38 metres Chart Datum (2.65 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, the main road at Northney will flood. At South Hayling, strong winds and moderate to large waves could move shingle on the beach. Some minor impact garden and road flooding may occur at Southwood Road, Bembridge Drive, Meath Close and The Strand. At 01:45 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide may be similar in magnitude. We will issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. We are liaising with the local authority over the beach condition at South Hayling. Avoid South Hayling seafront at high tide. Shingle and debris can be thrown by strong winds and large waves. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds and moderate waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.46 m. The total forecast tide is 5.38 metres Chart Datum (2.65 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 30 minutes either side of high water, spray overtopping of sea defence walls into low lying coastal roads is expected between Hillhead and Gosport, namely Cliff Road and Stokes Bay Road. At Hillhead, low lying sea front car parks may flood. Property flooding is not expected. At 01:45 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide may be similar in magnitude. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. Be careful if driving, parking or walking at Gosport sea front at high tide. Some shingle and debris could reach and impact the main road at Stokes Bay. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the first forecast high water is 21:30 on 07/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.40 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 9 in a westerly direction. The time and date of the second forecast high water is 09:45 on 08/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 6.95 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 8 in a westerly direction. 
There is a possibility of flooding for the Severn estuary at Severn Beach, including New Passage and Pilning. Conditions may apply one/two hours either side of the high tide.
Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Rame Head to Plymouth including tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Tuesday 7th December. High water at Plymouth is at 20:04. Times of high water will vary along the coast 

Strong Force 7 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 5m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Locations particularly at risk include: Kingsand, Cawsand, harbours and coastal car parks, ferry terminals and quaysides exposed to the open sea and vulnerable to large waves.  Expect tides to be around 350mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.  

With strong winds and large waves, sea front areas will be dangerous. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.  

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.  

This message will be updated on the morning of Wednesday 8th December.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:

Strong Force 7 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 5m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations Fowey: Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay and Caffa Mill Car park Looe: East Looe & West Looe quaysides, and Quay Road. Edge of quays likely to flood include any low-lying car parks, with particular emphasis on Fowey, and East & West Looe.  Expect tides to be around 350mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.   

With strong winds and large waves, sea front areas will be dangerous. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.  

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

Strong Force 7 westerly winds, and offshore wave heights of over 5m, are forecast to cause wave over-topping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations in Mounts Bay.  Expect tides to be around 350mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Tuesday. Winds are forecast to be South South Westerly Force 8 gusting to 50 knots at times.
Time off high water at locations along the East Dorset Coast is as follows:
Weymouth Preston Beach at 08:30 AM and 09:00 PM,
Swanage Bay at 10:20 AM and 11:15 PM,
Poole Harbour at Wareham at 12:00 mid day and 01:45 AM on Wednesday,
and Christchurch Harbour at 02:00 PM and 01:30 AM on Wednesday.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Stay away from exposed beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Tuesday. Winds are forecast to be South South Westerly Force 8 gusting to 50 knots at times.
Time of high water at locations along the West Dorset Coast is at 08:45 AM and 09:15 PM on Tuesday 07/12/2021
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Stay away from exposed beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Avoid walking close to cliffs due to the high risk of rock falls in the prevailing conditions.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Tuesday's tide at 10:30 AM  and 00:30 AM on Wednesday will be higher than normal due to stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include Wareham Quayside and Hamworthy.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds and moderate waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.51 m. The total forecast tide is 5.43 metres Chart Datum (2.70 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, road and car park flooding will affect Langstone High Street, The Royal Oak and Ship Inn Pub (Langstone), South Street, Queen Street and the A259 junction of Lumley Road. In Emsworth, the promenade may become open harbour. Isolated property flooding is expected. At Bridge Road, the tide may rise to the top of the river bank for a short period of time. At 01:45 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide level remains elevated, but it is unlikely to cause flooding to property. We'll issue further advice. To help protect property, we have installed drop boards at Emsworth Promenade (on the south side of the Mill Pond). If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Easterly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.51 m. The total forecast tide is 5.43 metres Chart Datum (2.70 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will exceed the top of the slipway at Lower Quay, which could impact a very small number of properties in this location. The lower end of Wallington Shore Road and the road at Eastern Parade will flood. Flood water in Wallington Shore Road will be between 0.1 m and 0.2 m deep. At 01:45 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide level remains elevated, but it is unlikely to cause flooding to property. We will issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. At Town Quay, if you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. Cars should not park at the lower end of Wallington Shore Road. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:41 and 14:34 on 07/12/2021 is higher than normal due to Storm Barra, which brings strong South Easterly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.54 m. The total forecast tide is 4.32 metres Chart Datum (2.32 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 1 hour either side of high water, Palace Lane and the B3056 (Hatchet Lane) north of the Mill Pond will flood. Access to the village will be temporarily difficult. On the downstream side of the pond, the Mill House garden will flood. At 01:18 and 03:18 on 08/12/2021‚ the tide level is forecast to be slightly lower, but it will still cause minor impact flooding. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. To reduce flood risk to property, please drive slowly through Beaulieu, avoiding it completely if possible. At Hatchet Lane, driving through flood water can cause flooding to property. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/12/2021.

Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding is possible for the duration of the strong winds, between 15:30 and 19:30 on Tuesday, 07/12/21.  Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, especially at Sunderland Marine Walk Outer and Port of Sunderland Harbour. High winds and coastal conditions are expected to continue throughout the day and afternoon, and will start to ease during Tuesday evening, 07/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on 07/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the forecast high water is 21:30 on 07/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.40 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 9 in a westerly direction. There is a possibility of flooding for the Severn estuary at the Severn Estuary at Oldbury-on-Severn, Northwick and Avonmouth including Aust and Old Passage. Conditions may apply one/two hours either side of the high tide.

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding is expected at North Shields Western Quay Prom for the duration of the strong winds, between 16:00 and 18:15 on Tuesday, 07/12/21. High winds and coastal conditions are expected to continue throughout the day and afternoon, and will start to ease during Tuesday evening, 07/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on 07/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Victoria Harbour, Hartlepool
items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding is expected at Town Wall and Croft on Heugh for the duration of the strong winds, between 16:00 and 19:00 on Tuesday, 07/12/21.  High winds and coastal conditions are expected to continue throughout the day and afternoon, and will start to ease during Tuesday evening, 07/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on 07/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:30 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.11 m. The total forecast tide is 6.89 metres Chart Datum (3.37 mAOD) at Newhaven. For 2 hours either side of high water, a small amount of spray overtopping will affect footpaths, sea front parking and the road at Marine Parade and the Esplanade. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, and flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. At low tide we will check and work to maintain the condition of the shingle beach which helps to protect the town from flooding. Avoid walking, parking and driving along Seaford Sea Front at high tide. Spray and water will contain and scatter shingle which is dangerous. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.09 m. The total forecast tide is 7.49 metres Chart Datum (3.84 mAOD) at Eastbourne. For 2 hours either side of high water, the road at Herbrand Walk may flood, and could be impassable to traffic. Beach top properties at Pevensey Bay will be affected by spray, caused by the large waves. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, and flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. To protect property from flooding, at low tide, Pevensey Coastal Defence Ltd will maintain the condition of the shingle beach. Avoid Pevensey beach at high tide. Spray and waves will contain and scatter shingle which is dangerous. As a precaution, plan driving routes to avoid Herbrand Walk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021

items.description: Coastal areas of Rustington to Shoreham
items.message: Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 08/12/2021 is forecast to be 30cm lower than Tuesday, but with much bigger waves and strong South Westerly Force 6 winds due to Storm Barra. The weather increases tide table values by 0.16 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, spray overtopping will affect footpaths and esplanades including Marine Drive at Ferring, West and Marine Parade, Worthing and West Beach and Shoreham Beach, Shoreham. Shingle and ponded water could affect the A259 near Brooklands. Strong winds will continue until Thursday. However, wave heights, tide levels, flood impacts and risk should reduce from Wednesday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast. We may inspect the condition of the beach at low tide. Stormy seas are dangerous. Avoid walking along the sea front over high tide, shingle can be contained, carried and thrown in larger waves and spray. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/12/2021
